instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
I have the above, clean as a whistle no liquid damage at all anywhere on the board.

USB showing 5v.

Checked <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and it was 0v shorted to ground. Located <CAPACITOR>C7081</CAPACITOR> to be problem, replaced and now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> shows 2.2v.

Removed <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> and pin 1 is 3.42v so that problem is on the board side.

I've checked diode mode the caps around all the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and they are all 2.2v and 0.33(d) 

I've used a thermal camera but obviously as it's not shorted it didn't show anything

Any help in trying to locate the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> goes hot?
If not, you can play with <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>/11/13 to adjust 3.3V, instead of 2.2V.
You can try shorting <RESISTOR>R6913</RESISTOR> first, but may be not enough.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6903</CHIP> not getting hot.

Before I start playing with the resistors to try and get 3.42v I thought I would removed <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> applied 3.42v with 2amp Pin 2 and connected the powerline at the same time and I got 20v Apple logo and boot to the login screen.

I've put <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> back and it's back at 2.2v. On pin 1 without the <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> on I get 3.42v

The only thing I have noticed is a missing, i think it's a cap, from the Hall sensor block., but this wouldn't make any difference to the drop , I would have thought.

Any thoughts??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
If you got the machine working in that way, the you must play with mentioned resistors.
<RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> must be soldered of course.
In order to increase <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, you must reduce lower resistor (<RESISTOR>R6911</RESISTOR>), or increase upper resistor (<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
I don't really want to do that as there has to be a reason why it's dropping to 2.2v and this MacBook once repaired will be going out of the country and I don't really wan to pay the shipping charges back if it goes faulty again.

The only thing that isn't working correctly is the left speaker( when looking at it from the keyboard topside) when you turn the volume up full and play base it cut's out. If you leave it for a while it will come back on again. Apart from that everything else is working... I will continue the search for the dropping voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> showing 2.2volts [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Found the problem it was <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> - replaced and now its working again.

Just thought I would share the solution to this.. I applied 3.42v to the system side and reduced the amps to see what was the lowest I would get, this was 0.04amps and made me think that at such a low amp it can't be a problem on the system. I then start to measure from R607 and noticed that when I got to <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> on one side I was getting 5.12v but on the other it was 3.36v and bingo problem found.
